messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Primped/doctored tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Milt, If it is actively corroding you should stop it.  There is no sense in allowing a piece to degrade in your care.  If the sukashi is extremely fragile,
messages.messageBody:
Milt,
If it is actively corroding you should stop it. There is no sense in allowing a piece to degrade in your care. If the sukashi is extremely fragile, maybe a drop of camellia oil would be the right approach. It will darken the rust (a lot), but obviously that is not as bad as damaging the iron. If a tool is required to scrape, I'd pick a very thin, flexible one that would bend with less force that it'd take to damage the sukashi.

Any other ideas on stabilizing corrosion in a sensitive area like this?

Jim

one more question..........
what if there are active red rust in the opening ? leave it alone to
continue doing structural damage ? Some of the early sukashi guards
have very " thin " opening and I have seen some iron can literally
fell off with the slightest touch............

milt


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.messageBody:
--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Jim Gilbert" <jggilbert@E...>
wrote:

> A piece that has been cleaned to the point that it looks younger
than it should can be a problem. This is where cleaning out the

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Primped/doctored tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Ken, ... Usually. ... Yes. A clumsy repatination, resurfacing of the piece, major rusting, paint, shoe polish, etc., will result in a failure. OTOH, a
messages.messageBody:
Ken,

>I would think that papered pieces would not be very primped.

Usually.

>Wouldn't the judges be fairly good at detection and the piece's score would be negatively impacted by such a discovery?

Yes.

A clumsy repatination, resurfacing of the piece, major rusting, paint, shoe polish, etc., will result in a failure.

OTOH, a perfectly done restoration that is exactly right for the original piece will be no problem.

The in between stuff will have a point consequence. Condition counts.

Cleaning off rust is of course OK as long as the surface isn't damaged, but pits will remain and they will count against condition.

A piece that has been cleaned to the point that it looks younger than it should can be a problem. This is where cleaning out the sukashi openings can hurt you even if you personally like the way that looks. If the age cues are contradictory, the judgment tends to go to the younger date. The object of conservation or even restoration is not to make the guard look new.

Clear wax isn't going to help a bad surface at shinsa, but it shouldn't hurt a good one either. If an owner really likes his pieces waxy or lives on the ocean it shouldn't be a big problem, since the wax can be seen through and is not a permanent coating. I suppose that someone could come up with a way to over do it to the point where the guard looks so strange that the real origin comes into question.

Polishing guards to the point where the surface becomes shiny and looses surface character is a problem. Burnishing obscures the traits of the iron necessary for kantei. It's really a slower process to get to the same place as resurfacing and/or poor repatination.

Like Ron said, look at all of the great pieces you can get your eyes on and remember them.
Jim




Hi all,


Jim G's input on what is acceptable for papers would
be interesting.

Ken


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Primped/doctored tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Curran - It is probably wise to become familiar with some of the enhancements techniques used on iron tsuba, simply to recognize them when you come across
messages.messageBody:
Hi Curran -

It is probably wise to become familiar with some of the "enhancements" techniques used on iron tsuba, simply to recognize them when you come across them. More important though, would be to jump at any opportunity to actually "see" first-hand, truly first class iron tsuba and to let your mind absorb (even subconsciously) what you are seeing. The Higo display and Jim Gilbert's sukashi display (which I missed) in Chicago was super! These days, each show has similar displays for us to enjoy. I believe Bill Miller did one on Satsuma tsuba last Tampa show. Check out those "high dollar" tsuba on dealers' tables. San Francisco had a fair number of Juyo tsuba (and other kodogu) out for sale. Evenually, exposing yourself to this real "art" quality--what's really fine art--will (hopefully) develop into a better appreciation of iron tsuba, and you will find yourself passing over the hundreds of average works and homing in on that one tsuba that has that "something extra" which your mind is drawing you to. Buy that one!

Long winded yes, but you see what I'm getting at. Personally, I continue to admire lots of different tsuba but when that special one comes along, hopefully, I'll grab it.

Ron
STL
----- Original Message -----
From: Curran Campbell
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Friday, September 24, 2004 4:20 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Primped/doctored tsuba


Hee hee...
I fell for that trick too, ... once. Luckily, wasn't
that painful. Sold the tsuba 'as is' for about 2/3
what I paid. Didn't like it enough to spend the time
on it.

The only problem with starting a folder of 'doctored'
tsuba is that photography mutes a lot. A friend has
shown me tsuba from one dealer who's photos look
honest, huge, and scanned in. Then he shows me several
tsuba from that dealer, in hand: much smaller, and
some are 'ugly'. I assume doctored, because the I've
seen one before/after that the dealer bought when I
restrained knowing the very nice tsuba would require 1
year of generally accepted Tender Loving Care.

You would think smaller scale would mute what is shown
huge and 3D.

But there are lot of tsuba where I can't tell if they
have been doctored. My last lines of defense are
maginification glass / loupes and that I've got a
strong sense of smell and a biochem background. So it
comes down to some nice noonday sunlight, a magnifier,
and a few cautious sniffs (hey, it works. Just don't
sneeze.).

Curran


--- David Zincavage <jdz@...> wrote:

> Well, when I look at tsuba priced in the high three
> figues and above on the usual dealer websites, and
> they resemble $200 Ebay tsubas in form and basic
> aesthetic quality, but seem somehow peculiarly more
> beautiful, more magnificent, downright wrapped in
> glory, like the advantageously lit men's clothing in
> the windows of J. Press, I figure those dealers
> know something I don't know about how to gussy a
> tsuba up. Just like the guy who photographed his
> rusty Akasaka tsuba on an orange background, and
> then sold it to me. There are special skills and
> tricks of the trade.
>
>

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Primped/doctored tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Well, when I look at tsuba priced in the high three figues and above on the usual dealer websites, and they resemble $200 Ebay tsubas in form and basic
messages.messageBody:
Well, when I look at tsuba priced in the high three figues and above on the usual dealer websites, and they resemble $200 Ebay tsubas in form and basic aesthetic quality, but seem somehow peculiarly more beautiful, more magnificent, downright wrapped in glory, like the advantageously lit men's clothing in the windows of J. Press, I figure those dealers know something I don't know about how to gussy a tsuba up. Just like the guy who photographed his rusty Akasaka tsuba on an orange background, and then sold it to me. There are special skills and tricks of the trade.


----- Original Message -----
From: steven
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Friday, September 24, 2004 1:34 PM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: Primped/doctored tsuba


Hi Bob,

Yes, this is a great site... :o). I have spent quite a bit of time here,
and it's a wealth of information, no doubt. I think what I'm looking
for, though, is to actually see some good close-up photos of a
waxed, lacquered, or otherwise primped tsuba. Sometimes it's
easier to understand when a piece is doctored via visuals than
by desciption only... Thanks much for the response, Bob.

Steve

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Primped/doctored tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Hi all, I would think that papered pieces would not be very primped.  Wouldn t the judges be fairly good at detection and the piece s score would be negatively
messages.messageBody:
Hi all,

I would think that papered pieces would not be very
primped. Wouldn't the judges be fairly good at
detection and the piece's score would be negatively
impacted by such a discovery? One for Jim G. to
answer?

Getting ivory is simple, look on ebay. I found lots
of piano keys listed if I remember correctly, although
I purchased a lot of broken ivory pieces. The netsuke
that came in the lot had a great red inplanted
signature, too bad the head was cut off. I traded it
for some repro menuki, that are nice quality but I
don't know what to do with them at the moment. I
figured better than a netsuke with no head.

Jim G's input on what is acceptable for papers would
be interesting.

Ken

messages.subject: Primped/doctored tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Greetings all, I was wondering if any of you might have some good photos of tsuba that illustrate in detail evidence of primping.  As a newbie in tsuba study
messages.messageBody:
Greetings all,

I was wondering if any of you might have some good photos of
tsuba that illustrate in detail evidence of primping. As a newbie
in tsuba study and collecting, it would be SO helpful to actually
SEE pictures of such primping (wax, lacquer, etc...), as well as to
see some before and after pictures of tsuba with rust issues
and then "post- rust issues"... If a folder could be opened in the
"photos" section of the group here, I think it would be really
beneficial, especially to rookies like me! Just a thought...

Steve
